results.title: Roar culture
results.brief_description:
‘Roar culture’ is a successful six month community arts project that was documented on video. The project brought together schools, community groups, artists, people from culturally diverse backgrounds and local government, including over 80 students, 10 storytellers, and 14 artists/mentors. ‘Roar culture’ explores issues of identity concerning ethnic, religious & sexual discrimination, cultural diversity and tolerance.
In doing so, it was critical to the process that there was a space for understanding and insight: a space where the many faces and voices which contribute to Bendigo’s historical and contemporary image and identity, were paid attention.
Stage one: the project’s starting point was the narrative or story. Stories from 10 multicultural & indigenous individuals whose memories ranged from the 1930s through to today, from places and countries which hauntingly navigated us to Bendigo. Each told a different story about living in regional Victoria however the threads of isolation, language difficulties, fragmented families and broader cultural or religious differences provided significant links.
Stage two was a mentor program, which furthered the developed the artistic skills of the students through a variety of cultural & arts mediums. These included workshops exploring Aboriginal dance; Japanese movement and theatre; contemporary and traditional music from a cross section of cultures; photojournalism and visual art mediums.
Stage three included a series of round table discussions and practical workshops uniting the stories of Stage One with the skills development of Stage Two. This enabled scripts & a musical score to be written for the final stage.
Stage four included performance rehearsals & backstage skills development which culminated in an experimental performance through multi-disciplined artforms in the round at The Capital Theatre on July 16 &17 1999.
Participating in this project were students & teachers from Bendigo Senior Secondary College with members of the stage design crew from Girton Grammar School and Catholic College. An original score of music was composed by local musicians and performed by the Bendigo Youth Orchestra. Financial partners were City of Greater Bendigo, Festivals Australia, The Myer Foundation & Victorian Multicultural Commission.
‘Roar culture’ was awarded the 1999 Local Government & the Arts Leadership Award for Best Practice Management of a Cultural Project

Lynda Newton
Project & Artistic Director

results.title: Woomera 2002
results.creator_credit: Anthony Snowden, Tom McKendrick, Laurel Heisman and SKA TV
results.brief_description: During Easter 2002, activists from around Australia converged upon Woomera Detention Centre to protest the federal government’s mandatory detention of refugees. Activists coordinated with the detainees’ protests within the detention centre, resulting in the mass breakout of 50 refugees. Most of the escapees were returned to the detention centre, but 11 detainees achieved freedom. The activists continued to protest the inhumane treatment of refugees in detention throughout the weekend, expressing their solidarity with both the detained refugees and also the people that escaped. This incident led to an increase in global awareness surrounding mandatory detention policies in Australia
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anthony Snowden, Tom McKendrick, Laurel Heisman and SKA TV

results.title: Global insights 4
results.creator_credit: Ntennis Davi, Campbell Manderson, Tom McKendrick and SKA TV
results.brief_description:
Global Insights 4 is a compilation of short video works of a subversive political nature, sourced from videoactivists, cultural saboteurs and ‘serious’ documentary-makers from around the world.
Pieces featured include an alternative US response to the incidents of September 11 2001, made by Indymedia NYC soon after the event; scenes from the front line of the democracy struggle in Malaysia. A remarkable sequence of (unarmed) indigenous peasants in Mexico taking over an army base; a Korean perspective on the rise of the new global economic orthodoxy and the resistance to it; the ‘no borders’ movement in Europe and Australia against the deportation and detention of refugees.
Adverts peppered throughout the program are actually ‘subverts’ - biting satirical 30-second statements about consumerism, gender, sexuality and possibilities for reshaping the world. Producers of this form range from disaffected advertisers to teenagers with an ironic message about climate change.
The Global Insights videos have seen hundreds of free public screenings from Tamil Nadu to Antarctica - inspiring grass-roots people’s action and fostering an independent and accessible screen culture globally.
Global Insights is put together on a miniscule budget by volunteers. It is a collaboration between hundreds of independent media makers around the world.

results.title: First Touch
results.brief_description: Using archival films of the Apollo lunar missions in the late 1960s and early 70s, this 2 screen video installation contemplates humankind’s first touch of the moon. Often considered a giant leap in human development, the video concentrates on the delicate and hesitant movements of the astronauts and their spaceships as they overcome the limits of outer space. With both humour and melancholy, stunning images of the moon, the earth, and the astronauts and their spacecraft, are interwoven into a wondrous contemplation of this extraordinary achievement.

results.title: End Game
results.creator_credit: Emma Crimmings, Michael Fairlie and Rhys Graham
results.brief_description: Using the fragments, clock leaders and strips of films found at the beginning and end of hundreds of old 16mm films, this Public Imaging work explores the visual beauty of the film’s surface. Concealed among ACMI’s vast film collection, these pieces of film are a testament to the aging wonder of celluloid. The play of light and colour that can be found in the interweaving of these accidents and offcuts makes for a hypnotic experience.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Emma Crimmings, Michael Fairlie and Rhys Graham

results.title: Gather
results.brief_description: A restrained, observational study of the groupings, gestures, and postures of people who gather to form temporary communities in the city. People are observed gathering for entertainment, for commemoration, for debate and contestation, for celebration. The city is seen as a shifting flux and flex of momentary comminglings.

results.title: Hurt
results.creator_credit: BIG hART, Phillip Crawford and Rhys Graham
results.brief_description: ‘Hurt’ is an extraordinary project in which film and video cameras were put in the hands of 250 under-privileged young people from rural regions of northern New South Wales and Western Victoria. The basic materials derived from this process comprised hundreds of poignant, beautiful, cruel and comforting stories. Filmmakers Phillip Crawford and Matthew Priestly from youth arts organization BIG hART worked with the young people to create an AFI award winning film, ‘Hurt’ in which fragmented, poetic and haunting stories of isolation and hardship are told through the words and images created by the young artists. In this new ACMI commissioned project filmmakers from BIG hART have turned the material into a multi-screen spatial installation that puts the viewer into the midst of this fragmented world of broken lives, beauty and bravery.
